column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=Classic Maya city heavily looted in the 1960s and 1970s .
#Text=The Classic Maya city of El Zotz is located within the San Miguel la Palotada National Park , 20 km west of the major Maya site of Tikal in Guatemala ’ s northern Petén province .
#Text=Originally called Pa ’ Chan , the site was known as Dos Aguadas until 1977 when archaeologist Marco Antonio Bailey registered it as El Zotz with the Guatemalan government .
#Text=He appears to have changed the name to distinguish it from another ‘ Dos Aguadas ’ recorded by William Bullard in 1960 .
#Text=The site is contained within a75 by.75 km square and is covered by tropical forest .
#Text=During the Late Classic war between the polities of Tikal and Calakmul , El Zotz appears to have allied itself with Calakmul .
#Text=This alliance appears to have signalled the end for El Zotz : the last known inscription to refer to the city describes it as being the target of an attack from Tikal .
#Text=Like most remote jungle sites , El Zotz fell victim to the wave of systematic looting which devastated the Petén in the 1960s and 1970s .
#Text=Looters even carved their names and the dates of their digging on some of the monuments at the site .
#Text=It was news of the looting at El Zotz that both inspired Bailey ’ s visit in December 1977 , and brought archaeologists Ian Graham and then George Andrews to the site in 1978 .
#Text=Almost all of the nearly fifty buildings within the site core have been structurally compromised by looters ’ trenches and tunnels .
#Text=Indeed , by 1983 when archaeologists with the Proyecto Nacional Tikal visited the site to assess looting damage , all buildings of notable size or importance had been looted .

#Text=Archaeologist Stephen Houston has recorded more than 89 individual looters ’ trenches at the site , some of which pass completely through entire pyramids.This looting activity has seriously destabilised the site ’ s monumental structures .
#Text=Beyond the expected damage due to looters tunnels , some of the structures have suffered from the removal of carved architectural elements .
#Text=Some buildings at El Zotz once boasted carved lintels : decorative bars that served as structural elements within temple doorways .
#Text=The removal of these lintels for sale on the art market can lead to a building collapse .
#Text=In 1989 a Guatemalan archaeological team with the Proyecto Nacional Tikal was forced to undertake major stabilisation works on Temple 1 at El Zotz related to the removal of lintels by looters .
#Text=The team installed new lintels in an effort to keep the building standing , and were forced to seal off some of the more unstable rooms and areas of the structure .
#Text=A wooden lintel , looted from the site sometime in the late 1960s or 1970s and returned to Guatemala from the Denver Museum of Art in 1998 , originally came from Temple 1 .
#Text=Epigraphic research may be able to connect a number of unprovenienced vessels in private collections to the looting of El Zotz .
#Text=Stephen Houston notes that the rulers of El Zotz all used a single name composed of the symbol for ‘ great ’ , a fish , and an animal head .

#Text=On an unprovenienced vase associated with El Zotz , the name ‘ a-ku ’ or turtle is added to this formulation and this variation of the El Zotz ruler name connects about a dozen vases in private collections .
#Text=Two examples that Houston offers are a vase owned by the Mint Museum of Art in Charlotte , North Carolina and another owned by the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University .

#Text=These vessels are all stylistically and iconographically similar and Houston believes that they will eventually be linked conclusively to El Zotz , perhaps with the aid of scientific analysis if they are ever made available for study .
